Fine particulate matter (PM2.5) can penetrate deep into the lungs and bloodstream, causing respiratory and cardiovascular disease. It can worsen asthma, reduce lung function, and increase the risk of heart attacks.
Coarse particulate matter (PM10) can cause respiratory issues, aggravate asthma, and contribute to bronchitis and other lung diseases. It\'s especially harmful to children and the elderly.
Ozone (O3) can cause inflammation of the airways, reduce lung function, and worsen asthma. Prolonged exposure can lead to permanent lung damage.
Nitrogen dioxide (NO2) can irritate the respiratory system, reduce lung function, and increase susceptibility to respiratory infections. Long-term exposure may contribute to asthma development.
Sulfur dioxide (SO2) can cause respiratory irritation, aggravate asthma, and make breathing difficult. It may worsen existing heart and lung diseases.
Carbon monoxide (CO) reduces the blood\'s ability to carry oxygen, leading to reduced oxygen delivery to vital organs. High levels can cause headaches, dizziness, confusion, and even death.
This pollutant can have negative effects on respiratory and cardiovascular health, especially in sensitive individuals such as children, the elderly, and those with pre-existing conditions.
